theory: Imu Created the Florian Triangle Shadows
author: Dexerto / One Piece Community
theoryText: The theory proposes that Imu, the supreme leader of the World Government, created the mysterious giant shadows with red eyes that inhabit the Florian Triangle. Evidence includes the physical similarities between these shadows and Imu's silhouette, particularly the red eyes. Chapter 1085 shows Imu manifesting shadows of all shapes and sizes that resemble those seen in Thriller Bark. The shadows specifically target pirates, which aligns with Imu's hostility toward seafarers. The theory suggests either Imu deploys these shadows to eliminate pirates exploring dangerous waters, or there's something hidden in the Florian Triangle that the World Government wants to keep secret.
evidenceProvided: Physical similarities between Florian Triangle shadows and Imu's silhouette
Red eyes present in both entities
Chapter 1085 shows Imu can manifest shadows of various shapes and sizes
The massive scale of the shadows matches Imu's demonstrated power

theory: Moria as Luffy's Dark Reflection and Tragic Villain
author: Worstgen Community
theoryText: Gecko Moria represents a shadow or dark reflection of Monkey D. Luffy - what Luffy could become if he lost his crew. The theory posits that Moria is a tragic villain whose reliance on zombies and stolen shadows stems from PTSD after watching his original crew killed in battle with Kaido. The Mysterious Four all represent corrupted versions of the Straw Hats, showing what happens when dreams are pursued through shortcuts and stolen power rather than genuine bonds and personal growth. Moria's dream to become Pirate King mirrors Luffy's, but his methods - stealing others' strength rather than building his own - highlight the contrast between genuine and corrupted ambition.
evidenceProvided: Both Moria and Luffy want to become Pirate King
Moria lost his original crew to Kaido, creating trauma
Moria's reliance on others' power (stolen shadows) vs. Luffy's personal growth
The Mysterious Four parallel the Straw Hat crew structure
Moria's zombie army represents forcing loyalty rather than earning it

author: One Piece Community (Recent Discussions)
theoryText: With recent revelations about Moria's history with Kaido and Wano, some fans theorize that Moria's zombie army and shadow-stealing activities were not purely for selfish ambition, but rather a desperate attempt to amass enough power to challenge Kaido again and possibly liberate Wano. The 'Ultimate Special Zombie' he plans to create with Luffy's shadow (worth 300,000,000 in fighting power) could represent his attempt to create a warrior strong enough to defeat a Yonko. This reframes Moria not as a simple villain, but as someone who chose morally questionable methods to achieve what he saw as a righteous goal - avenging his fallen crew and stopping Kaido.
evidenceProvided: Moria's original crew was killed by Kaido
The scale of his zombie army suggests preparation for a massive battle
His focus on obtaining the strongest shadows possible
Recent manga revelations about Moria's connection to Wano
His continued antagonism toward Kaido even after Thriller Bark

theory: Shadowless Victims and Sunlight Vulnerability Logic
author: Anime & Manga Stack Exchange Community
theoryText: A logical question arises: if people who lose their shadows are destroyed by sunlight, why does Moria release them back to sea where they'll inevitably die? The theory suggests several possibilities: 1) Moria is cruel and enjoys their suffering, 2) The victims serve as warnings to other pirates about Thriller Bark's danger, 3) Moria doesn't want corpses piling up on his ship, or 4) There's a strategic reason to spread fear about the Florian Triangle. The discussion also explores whether shadowless victims could survive if they simply stayed in darkness indefinitely, or if there are other factors at play beyond just sunlight exposure.
evidenceProvided: Brook survived 5 years without his shadow by avoiding sunlight
Moria releases victims knowing they'll die in sunlight
The Florian Triangle's perpetual fog provides some protection
Creating fear serves Moria's interests in controlling the area
